review_blob:
first thing i thought of the aroma was moss.
kinda has a dirty old world smell to it... with hints of spice... pours a light coppery orange, with slight lacing. a lot lighter than i would have expected, im not too well versed in saisons, but these spice seems to be a tad bit overbearing in this one...
a nice summer beer at the very least.

on first smell, this reminded me of dogfish heads immort ale. this is a good thing. esp. since i usually dont care for nut browns, or brown ales of any kind for that matter. pours a syrupy ruby-brown, with slight tan head. aroma is sweet and almost buttery. very smooth, full and creamy, with balance between sweet and bitter. expected typical (nut) brown ale flavors really are only evident in the finish. I like this. and thats saying a lot; considering my predisposition towards brown ales (as ive repeated over and over in this review)

pours clear gold, with frothy white head. aroma has hints of the saaz hops, but also offers classic belgian maltiness and yeastiness. quite surprised by the hop profile of this... has a beautiful finish, with linger hop bitterness on the tongue.
a well-done marriage of the two styles.... would be a great intro to belgian ales for a hophead.

dark brown/black pour w/ slighty tan head and lacing. coffee and chocolate notes all over the place, hop notes come though nicely, and balanced through and through. one of the best all around porters ive had, and would be a classic example of the breed.

pours a cloudy gold with frothy white head and evident carbonation... bubbly and all.
slight hints of moss underneath the characteristic wheat aromas... spicy, malty and slightly bitter at the back of the tongue just as you swallow. Ill follow suit with my roommates review immedietly before mine... not a wheat beer fan... but ill at least drink a couple of these every summer.

light brassy gold w/ white head.
extremely light... flavor lingers long on the finish,a nd actually leaves a decent hint of hoppiness. very crisp and refreshing, despite the fact that i really dont care for lagers much.

pours thick black, with brown head that quickly disappears. aroma is loaded with coffee (fresh ground), hints of alcohol in the background, and caramel notes. flavors is coffee heavy, tastes almost like coffee with a shot of bourbon in it... has hints of chocolately creaminess. flavor lingers lightly on the palate. i would really enjoy this in a warmed glass. this beer is simply beautiful.
pours golden amber with minimal head. smells literally like a bag of pot.   flavor is hoppy, with hints of citrus. flavor lingers for quite a while with hops.

aroma is heavily yeasty with some hints of the pasture... pours faint gold with almost no head. mildly carbonated. flavor holds hints to Belgian yeasts, grass, a hint of spice... and is honestly a bit metallic in the finish.
beer_name: Heavy Seas Red Sky At Night

review_blob:
for starters... i dont remember this beer being this sweet.
huge floral hoppiness in aroma, underbitten by alcohol, which becomes more prominent as the beer has time to rest.
honestly, this isnt as bitter as i remember before. maybe its because ive become more beer-saavy in the past year... but the sweetness is almost too much in this.... i remember last years batch as being a kick in the face of hops. right now, i feel as if im drinking a not so syrupy hop liquor.
palate lingers for a while, but the sweetness lends to notes of caramel and takes away the hop backbone i recall from this.
this is still an incredible beer, but not as fantastic as i remember...
and ive been desperately watchign and waiting for this to hit the shelves since it was supposed to be released in March... here it is in mid-May, and we found it last week after hounding every beer and liquor store for months... and at our local beer-mecca pub. (Rich Os in New Albany, IN) 


again this is great, but not as brutally hoppy as i remember it to be.

pours slight amber, mild off white head.
aroma smells of roses, caramel, and hops.
 nicely balanced hop and malt profile.
flavor lingers slightly in typical pale ale fashion. nice.

beer_brewer_name: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
review_blob:
pours slightly frothy golden. aroma offers hints of caramel, malt and grass. 
matliness, with classic belgium flavors... nicely carbonated, tingly on the tongue. finish has slight sitrus notes and notes of toffee and malt.
not at all overly yeasty. very well balanced on all levels.
well done.

pours a rubyish amber with no head. smells of syrup, maple comes to mind first, then alcohol whiffs catch your sinuses. the sweetness of this makes it tought o swallow, but its still very well done.. as id expect from dogfish head. i wish i could have kept a bit of the carbonation and hop balance of the raison detre.

pours a sinfully black... looks and smells like a strong stout. the hoppiness is the only thing that could explain why this wasnt labeled as an imperial porter... well, that and its abv. roasted malts and hint of acidity... almost an espresso-like acidity actually. hop profile balances nicely, esp. w/ the carbonation. another first rate beer from dark horse.
beer_name: Dark Horse Reserve Special Black Ale

review_blob:
purchased while in Michigan over the 05 holidays...
pours orangish amber with slight white head. hints of grass and moss in the aroma.
flavor screams very tart apple cider. notes of sweetness come through, im lead to think  caramel typically... but the tartness makes me think of citrus. honestly... this doesnt really seem like a wheatwine. my first taste i literally said : Rodenbach. it tastes a lot like a flemish sour. good beer, not a daily drinker, but an interesting one to pull out and let some beer nerds try.

made a trip across the river to indiana and picked up this one...
aroma is almost overwhelming w/ blueberries. its beautiful.
pours so dark and thick i would guess this was an imperial. i was surprised at the abv based on its appearance ... but this is incredibly light and refreshing.
i never thought id say this... but this is one stout id sit out on the porch and drink during the summer.

Piney, extremely hoppy aroma... has hints of sweetness (syrup) as well. Rosey-amber colored pour from 22oz bottle. Flavor is quite hoppy, as expected - but has a nice amount of malty sweetness to contrast it and balance the beer out. Flavor lingers for quite a while between sips. A first rate beer all around.

dark brown/black with a brown head that disapears fast. a lot of alcohol in the aroma. a bit too much. sweet slightly roasty alcohol aroma. sweet chocolate fruity (banana) flavor. medium body. body seems a bit thin. fairly dry finish with quite a bit of alcohol.

Imperial stout? no. if this was labeled as a stout.... itd be awesome... calling it imperial... its weak.
hints of coffee, toasted wood... smoothy and mildly creamy... again... if this was a stout... itd be incredible... calling it an imperial though... it leaves much to be desired.

Draft. Too cold to develop aroma properlly. Slight hints of sweet oakiness. Surprisingly bitter throughout. Notes of coffee, chocolate, toffee, and smoke. Almost tart... like sour cherries. Flavor lingers forever. Nice. Makes me think of a strong porter almost. The only complaint i have is that i could hardly detect the barrel aging in this beer.

For starters... this is my daily drinker. If im buying a basic beer to drink and not really think about... i probally knock out 2 six-packs of this weekly. Not to mention that we have this on tap at the restaurant i work at... so its my nightly shift beer as well... Hence why i never got around to rating this.Pours medium golden with full frothy head. Aroma is blooming w/ hops. Honestly this beer is probaly a bit overly bitter... but ive grown a bit used to it. Hoppiness lingers in the mouth and begs me to drink more.

On draft at Rich Os for Gravity Head 2006. Cask pour, 2005 vintage; firkin. Sour, woody, almost fungus like aroma... like an old barn or basement (i cant believe i just typed that!) Tastes of dark caramel. Hints of apple and dried fruits. Heavy notes of currants. Fantastic!

On draft at Rich Os for Gravity Head 2006.Pours ruby red w/ a light head. Could barely etect any aroma... Flavor has apples, pear, slightly tart... dried cherries or raisins. Tastes like a Rodenbach Grand Cru if you cut the sourness. Perhaps the pour was too cold, lack of aroma dragged the score down. Excellent otherwise.
On draft at Rich Os for Gravity Head 2006. Golden with a slight white head. Yeasty w/ hints of citrus and malt. Nothing to write home about... but not at all bad.

On draft at Rich Os for Gravity Head 2006. brassy color, bubbly head. notes of banana, roasted pineapple in the aroma. hints of cigar tobacco on the mouth, mildly bitter and surprisingly light bodied.
pours medium amber with light creamy head.  sweet aroma. malty and slightly yeasty (if it was blind, id know it was a belgian is what i mean). nice and bubbly and has a lingering sweetness to it.
pour dark, with good size light brown head. lightly corbonated, and smooth. quite malty, and not overly bitter. nice toasty flavors lead towards a imperial stout.

pours hazy light amber. aroma leads hints of wheat and mild hops. surpisingly bitter for a lager, but still very light and refreshing. not sure what im picking up in this flavor wise... maybe pine. if i didnt know otherwise, id think this was an ale based on its hop-profile alone.

2006 vintage in 22oz bottle. brassy color with minimal whitish head. aroma gives samples of banana, caramel/toffee, nuts and hops. suprisingly syrupy and pushing towards sweet. hop bitterness is present, but not as strong as id have first expected... esp. in a beer from Stone. the 11.26% abv is well hidden in this beer w/ the exception of the syrupiness. yet another first rate brew from Stone.
smells incredibly of hops. strong hop flavor, but not overly bitter as id expect from a IPA2. usually id want it more bitter... but this is well balances. the flavor lingers slighty... its nice.

poured a cloudy golden, with minimal head. aromas of spice, coriander and some hnts of malt. suprisingly bitter for a wheat - likely due to the saaz hops used in the brew. one of the better wheats ive had, largely due to the balance of wheat and the bitterness of the hops.

pours light black with lacing on the edges... Aroma is chocolatey, with hints of berries.
Flavor has notes of coffee, but pretty weak body. not really all that full tasting... seems like this could be much better if the flavor was stronger, or at least lingered for a bit. Not horrible, but far from the best stout ive had.

Aroma is slightly acidic, but also yeasty and hints of nuts... Pours a medium dark amber with decent lacing. Flavor is quite sweet, leaning hard towards being syrupy, but has a nice hint of spice to round it out.
Flavor lingers on the palate for a few minutes, and the syrupiness makes for a nice mouth appeal in the end.
beer_name: Avery The Beast Grand Cru Ale

review_blob:
for starters...
this beer is a little weak to be an anniverasy ale. and i dont mean just in alcohol content. dont get me wrong... its a good solid beer... but nothing that im convinced is legendary.
Aroma is kinda fruity, sugary - almost apricot notes. Has almost a Belgium-style aroma to it.  Tastes of toasted malt (which is a high point for this beer), but has a very limited hop profile... in all truth, i think a bit more hops in the flavor would have balanced this out nicely; and leveled out the sweetness w/ some crisp bitter notes.

For starters....  my first flemish sour. It took us nearly 10 minutes to get the cork out of this thing.... it finally took a pair of pliers to get it to turn at all... and then another 5 minutes of work to weasel it out. Pours medium amber, with slight white head... 
Aroma is acidic (vinegary) tannic, and notes of vanilla and oak.
sour sour sour. i had no idea this is what they meant when sour was denoted... but holy hell. this is nice.
a nice contrast to the hoppy beers i love and drink regularly. wish i could find stuff like this locally - a roommate picked this up at Jungle Jims in Cinncinati.

Clasic english-style porter. smooth, dreamy... Somewhat reminds me of some stouts ive had... although more bitter.
a little smokey, but nothing overbearing.
a great session porter, but i can think of more inexpensive options id likely consider before. at $9 for a 4-pack... this was a bit pricey for what it is.

pours light brown head. nose is especially hoppy for a porter. this smells incredible! palate is a wonderful blend of coffee, chocolate, hops, and heaven. by far one of the best porters ive ever had. i usually write more in my reviews... but this stuff is too great to detail it into oblivion. go find this if you love porters (as i do)
beer_name: Three Floyds Alpha Klaus Christmas Porter

review_blob:
picked up while in Michigan for the holidays while beer hunting... pours black. ill agree w/ the others... looks like cola. nose is slightly acidic... lemons, but with bourbon barrel notes... faint vanilla, but nice balance of oak, chocolate and caramel. Though the listing for this says 10.5% abv.. my bottle states 9%, and has silkscreened label. despite this difference, i think the alcohol presence is noticable.. but well balanced. somewhat like a bourbon and coke... faint alcohol taste, but slightly watered down. its nice. this beer is slightly bitter, but the darker flavors lead me to a resemblance that i could only compare as a  light porter
im still picking up citrus notes... perhaps its from the charred oak.

pours blackish-brown with minimal head. nose is quite astringent and sharp. coffee, chocolate and cranberry notes in the aroma.
flavor is full-force, hops quite present. a lot better this (2nd) time around, than i remember from the first time i drank this.
alcohol is present, but not overly unpleasant.

pour deep black, with nice full forthy head.
nose is has slightly swet notes, and lacing coats glass fully, but settling quickly.

tastes esp. bitter for a porter, but im a fan of bitter beers, so this is a nice touch. oak notes in finish, but not detecting much clasic bourbon notes (vanilla, caramel, etc) My roommate gave me this for xmas, bought it before he tried it. he seemed a bit dissapointed w/ it, but im wuite enjoying this. nice an bitter porter with slight sweet notes to balance it... though im not detecting much of the bourbon barrel aging.

perhaps it was the manhattan i had earlier.
medium brown-amber pour with slight head. aroma is mildly spicy and carries typical belgium style yeast flavors, but not overbearing... some swet undertones and balanced by nice malt flavor.

European style all around, esp in the yeast flavor and hop aroma. the nose is light and i was pleasantly suprised to find a nice heavy bitterness and hoppiness come through on first taste. reminds me of some american craft brews in the style, but definately carries a european flavor. kind of thin body though.

pretty pathetic head for a lager.
no disrespect... but by far one of the worst beers ive had by such a quality craft brewery. id drink this over the liks of budweiser any day, but i feel like i should pour a pitcher of this and chug it till i puke (which wouldnt be hard)
this was honestly kinda hard to drink and harder to swallow.
drank from a snifter... furthering the heavy imperial stout aromas. i picked u[ notes of alcohol and coffee, and subtler notes of chocolate. very thick and coats the mouth incredibly.

First of all; was quite disappointed to discover this wasnt a corked bottle (i noticed before taking it home). I start on better notes: this is one of the better lagers ive had. And im not at a big fan of lagers.
The vanilla comes through w/ the malt in the nose, and through the body of the beer as you sip it. Tastes slightly flat, or at least under carbonated... but thats relative to comparison to other lagers.
Oak and caramal notes come through nicely through the bourbon barrel aging (any subtle vanilla notes from the wood are completely nulled by the addition of the whole vanilla bean.) thick and syrupy for a lager, and very sweet.
Alcohol is well hidden, but the bourbon notes keep reminding me of drinking bourbon on the rocks after the ice melts.
kinda tastes like watered down malty bourbon w/ loads of sugar and vanilla added. Mildy sharp finish with notes of cranberry.

not a bad beer by any means, but id likely reserve this as a one time beer. far from a daily drinker.

Chiptole Ale. at first, i coudl taste no hint of chiptole.  later it came through stronger... a nice beer, but nothing id want to drink everyday... left a somewhat spicy feeling in my stomach, like i just ate a spoonful of salsa.
the effect wasnt bad... but i was really expecting more... the first few drinks the flavor wasnt there... and when it came through.. i had kinda already made up my mind. interesting and worth trying...

honestly... after the expected fruit and floral aromas... i picked up a faint hint of cat piss. really. then i took a drink and smelled again, and it wasnt there...

a nice ale, great for summer...
but not exactly up to par w/ the rest of Bells beers... which is a strecth for me to say... im pretty torn between Bells and Rogue as my favorite brewery...
kinda sweet smelling, and faintly wheaty, but preey basic... id drink it over a lot of macro brews.... but nothing id preach about.

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: pours a massive head initially, then drops after a few minutes, to near nothing (hardly any lacing for me at all). yeasty, and definately pushing more to wheat than bock... but not too bad. id have gave the flavor more points if it had a better balance of wheat/bock flavors... the wheat flavors kinda took me off guard.
